questions.question_text:
You have an installation of MySQL 8 on Oracle Linux.
Consider the outputs:
//IMG//

Which statement is true about disk temporary tables for this installation?

comments.content:
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/internal-temporary-tables.html
tmp_table_size: From MySQL 8.0.28, tmp_table_size defines the maximum size of any individual in-memory internal temporary table created by the TempTable storage engine. When the tmp_table_size limit is reached, MySQL automatically converts the in-memory internal temporary table to an InnoDB on-disk internal temporary table
Sorry, innodb does use datadir for temporary tablespace. D is correct. When the size for the temporary table is large enough it switches to disk from memory,.

discussion.content: B, innodb has its own temporary tablespace

choices.E: Temporary tables will use the InnoDB temporary tablespace located in /tmp.
choices.C: Temporary tables are created in tmpdir only if configured to use MyISAM.
choices.B: Temporary tables will use the InnoDB temporary tablespace located in datadir.
choices.A: Only internal temporary tables from the optimizer will be created in tmpdir.
choices.D: Temporary tables are created in tmpdir only after they reach tmp_tabie_size.

comments.content:
I think ABD.
number of processes' nothing to do with secure environment.

discussion.content: ABC are the best i think

choices.F: Run MySQL server as the root user to prevent incorrect sudo settings.
choices.A: Restrict the number of OS users that have access at the OS level.
choices.D: Encrypt the file system to avoid needing exact file-system permissions.
choices.E: Keep the entire software stack on one OS host.
choices.B: Ensure appropriate file system privileges for OS users and groups.
choices.C: Minimize the number of non-MySQL Server-related processes running on the server host.

questions.question_text: Which three are requirements for a secure MySQL Server environment? (Choose three.)

choices.A: It will force the load of the audit plugin even in case of errors at server start.
choices.C: It prevents the audit plugin from being removed from the running server.
choices.D: It prevents the audit log from being removed or rotated.
choices.B: It causes the audit log to be created if it does not exist.

questions.question_text:
Examine this parameter setting:
audit_log=FORCE_LOG_PERMANENT
What effect does this have on auditing?

Your MySQL instance is capturing a huge amount of financial transactions every day in the finance database.
Company policy is to create a backup every day.
The main tables being updated are prefixed with transactions-.
These tables are archived into tables that are prefixed with archives- each month. mysqlbackup --optimistic-busy-tables="^finance\.transactions-.*" backup
Which optimization process best describes what happens with the redo logs?

choices.C: The redo logs are not backed up at all.
choices.B: The redo logs are backed up only if there are changes showing for the transactions tables.
choices.E: The transaction tables are backed up first, then the archive tables and redo logs.
choices.A: The redo logs are backed up first, then the transaction and archive tables.
choices.D: The archive tables are backed up first, then the transaction tables and redo logs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Optimistic phase: In this first phase, tables that are unlikely to be modified during the backup process (referred to as the “inactive tables” below, identified by the user with the optimistic-time option or, by exclusion, with the optimistic-busy-tables option) are backed up without locking the MySQL instance. And because those tables are not expected to be changed before the backup is finished, redo logs, undo logs, and system table spaces are not backed up by mysqlbackup in this phase.

comments.content: Not E, the unlikely tables are not transactional. E says transactional are first.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Optimistic phase: In this first phase, tables that are unlikely to be modified during the backup process (referred to as the “inactive tables” below, identified by the user with the optimistic-time option or, by exclusion, with the optimistic-busy-tables option) are backed up without locking the MySQL instance. And because those tables are not expected to be changed before the backup is finished, redo logs, undo logs, and system table spaces are not backed up by mysqlbackup in this phase.

Normal phase: In this second phase, tables that are not backed up in the first phase (referred to as the “busy tables” below) are being backed up in a manner similar to how they are processed in an ordinary backup: the InnoDB files are copied first, and then other relevant files and copied or processed with the MySQL instance locked. The redo logs, undo logs, and the system tablespace are also backed up in this phase.

Not A, not the last transaction of the master. It deals with the current sql being applied. 
"difference between the current timestamp on the replica and the original timestamp logged on the source for the event currently being processed on the replica."

So D. Time of slave and time it was run on the master, for the query just finished on the slave.

Selected Answer: A
This field is an indication of how “late” the replica is:

When the replica is actively processing updates, this field shows the difference between the current timestamp on the replica and the original timestamp logged on the source for the event currently being processed on the replica.

When no event is currently being processed on the replica, this value is 0.

choices.A: It is the time between the I/O thread receiving details of the master's last transaction and the time it was applied by the SQL thread.
choices.D: It is the time between the most recent transaction applied by a SQL thread and the time it was committed on the master.
choices.C: It is the time between the I/O thread receiving details of the master’s last transaction and the time it was written to the relay log on the slave.
choices.B: It is the time between the most recent transaction written to the relay logs and the time it was committed on the master.

questions.question_text:
You issue this command:

SHOW SLAVE STATUS -
In the output, there is a value for Seconds_behind_master.
How is this time calculated?
